subject.name: Compiler Design
subject.description: Covers the principles and techniques used in the design and implementation of compilers. Focuses on the phases of compilation, lexical and syntax analysis, semantic analysis, code generation, and optimization techniques.
objectives: To understand and list the different stages in the process of compilation
Identify different methods of lexical analysis
Develop algorithms to generate code for a target machine
Learn how to design and implement a compiler and study underlying theories with emphasis on imperative languages

units.title: Introduction and Lexical Analysis
topics: Lexical Analysis (scanner): Regular languages, finite automata, regular expressions
Conversion from regular expressions to finite automata

units.title: Syntax Analysis (Parser)
topics: LR(0), SLR(1), LR(1), LALR(1) grammars and bottom-up parsing

units.title: Semantic Analysis and Symbol Table
topics: Evaluation and flow of attributes in syntax trees
Symbol Table: structure, symbol attributes, and management
Run-time environment: procedure activation, parameter passing, value return, memory allocation, and scope

units.title: Intermediate Code Generation and Optimization
topics: Translation of different language features and intermediate forms
Code improvement and optimization: control-flow, data-flow dependence
Local and global optimization, loop optimization, peephole optimization
Architecture-dependent optimizations: instruction scheduling, cache optimization
Register allocation and target code generation

suggested_books: Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools by Alfred V. Aho, Ravi Sethi, and Jeffrey D. Ullman, Pearson Education
Compiler Design by Santanu Chattopadhyay, PHI
Modern Compiler Design by Dick Grune, Henri E. Bal, Ceriel J.H. Jacobs, and Koen G. Langendoen, Wiley Dreamtech
